questions.text: A patient presents with a fever and a red, tender, swollen left knee, which started two days ago. He was recently diagnosed with hypertension and started on hydrochlorothiazide. Immediate joint aspiration is done, and the microscopic picture is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
Which of the following drugs treats an acute episode of gout by binding to synovial tubulin thus inhibiting the migration of granulocytes into the joint ?
Which of the following drugs is not used in the management of chronic hyperuricemia?

A patient complains of persistent pain and stiffness over both his big toes and right knee over the past 2 years. X-ray of big toe showed deposition of uric acid crystals. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug of choice to reduce uric acid levels?
All of the following about allopurinol are incorrect except?

options.label: B
options.text: Allopurinol is largely bound to plasma proteins.

options.label: C
options.text: Allopurinol reduces the activity of azathioprine.

questions.correct_answer: D. Allopurinol is contraindicated during lactation.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of chronic gout presented with recurrent episodes of painful attacks despite being on allopurinol. His physician suggests a drug that inhibits the reabsorption of uric acid in the proximal tubules. Which of the following drugs uses this mechanism of action?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Class

Mechanism of Action

Use

Probenecid

Uricosuric agent

Inhibits URAT1 transporter → ↓ uric acid reabsorption → ↑ excretion

Chronic gout (under-excretors)

Febuxostat

Xanthine oxidase inhibitor

Inhibits xanthine oxidase → ↓ uric acid production

Chronic gout

Rasburicase

Uricolytic agent

Converts uric acid to allantoin (soluble)

Tumor lysis syndrome

Colchicine

Anti-inflammatory

Inhibits microtubule polymerization → ↓ neutrophil activity

Acute gout attacks

questions.text: A 75-year-old male with a history of gout presents to the clinic with increased frequency of gout attacks. His daily medications include rosuvastatin, low-dose aspirin and losartan for hypertension. He has been advised to avoid certain medications that can exacerbate his gout. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Drugs Associated with Gout

Drugs causing gout

Drugs beneficial in gout

Mnemonic – PAINED

  • P: Pyrazinamide
  • A: Aspirin (Normal dose <2 gms)
  • I: Immunosuppressive: Cyclosporine
  • N: Niacin
  • E: Ethambutol
  • D: Diuretic like loop diuretics, thiazides

Mnemonic – FALSe

  • F: Fenofibrate
  • A: Aspirin in toxic dose >5 gm
  • L: Losartan (OPTION B)
  • Se: Statins (Pravastatin, rosuvastatin) (OPTION D)

Treatment for drug-induced gout: Continue the drug + Allopurinol.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female presented to the hospital with early morning stiffness in her joints for the last few weeks. She reports severe pain in her right wrist and left knee. Increased CRP levels are seen in laboratory testing. What is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Rheumatoid Arthritis

Acute arthritis

 
  1. Mild-moderate
 
  • DOC: NSAIDs(OPTION B)
  • All except paracetamol (Piroxicam, Indomethacin, Aspirin, Diclofenac, Celecoxib
 

 2. Severe flare/ Resistant to NSAIDS

 

  • 1-2 joints: Intra-articular corticosteroids (Prednisolone, Triamcinolone)
  • >2 joints: Oral prednisolone

Long-term definitive treatment

 

DMARDs (Disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs)

 
  • DOC: Methotrexate (OPTION A)
  • Alternate: Hydroxychloroquine, Sulfasalazine, Infliximab etc. (OPTION D)
  • Action begins after 1 month
  • Not recommended for acute arthritis.
  • Bridge therapy – Start with corticosteroid and maintain the patient on DMARD.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female has been experiencing pain and stiffness in her wrists despite initial treatments. Her rheumatologist decides to start her on disease-modifying therapy (DMARDs). Which of the following statements incorrectly describes the mechanisms of action of the DMARDs? Methotrexate inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, reducing the production of DNA and RNA. Hydroxychloroquine inhibits T-cell activation and reduces the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. Sulfasalazine is metabolised to 5-aminosalicylic acid (5-ASA), which reduces inflammation of joints in rheumatoid arthritis (RA) Leflunomide inhibits the synthesis of purines, leading to a reduction in lymphocyte proliferation. Infliximab is an oral DMARD that acts by inhibiting interleukin-6.
questions.explanation:
DMARD’s

No.

Medication

Mechanism of Action

1.

Methotrexate (1) (anchor drug)

Inhibition of cytokine production, chemotaxis and cell mediated immune reaction.

2.

Hydroxychloroquine

Block lymphocyte proliferation like chloroquine but with longer action.

3.

Sulfasalazine

The sulfapyridine component blocks lymphocyte proliferation.

4.

Leflunomide

Inhibits DHOLD (Dihydro orotate dehydrogenase) and thymidylate synthase.

5.

Infliximab (I/V)

Certolizumab

Adalimumab

Golimumab

Etanercept

Anti-TNF𝛼

6.

Chloroquine

Inhibits IL1, IL6 TNF-Alpha in lymphocytes, reducing T cell activation.

7.

Tocilizumab

Sarilumab

Anti-IL-6

8.

Rituximab

Anti-CD-20

9.

Anakinra

Anti-IL-1

10.

Abatacept

Recombinant CTLA4, inhibits CD80/86

11.

Tofacitinib

Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors

12.

Penicillamine

Gold (Au)

Azathioprine

Inhibits macrophage and decreases IL-1

13.

Azathioprine

Cleaved to 6-mercaptopurine (6MP) and inhibit purine synthesis

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with a 3-year history of worsening joint pain presented to the clinic with early morning stiffness and swelling in her wrists. Her symptoms were not relieved with ibuprofen. A physical examination of the hands is shown. What is the most appropriate first-line treatment for her condition?

A 52-year-old female patient with a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for 5 years presents to the clinic with complaints of nausea, fatigue, mouth ulcers and an unusual rash on her legs. She has been on a stable regimen of DMARDs for the past few years. Laboratory investigations reveal a decreased Hb level, elevated liver enzymes, and mild leukopenia. Which drug is most likely responsible for her current symptoms?

A 52-year-old female with a 10-year history of rheumatoid arthritis has been on certain drug therapy for the past 5 years. She recently underwent an ophthalmological examination, where the ophthalmologist noted the presence of the following condition. What is the maximum recommended daily dose of the drug (in mg/kg) that is considered safe to minimise the risk of developing this condition?
questions.explanation:
Hydroxychloroquine

Mechanism of Action

Hydroxychloroquine⟶ Lysosome Accumulation ⟶ ↑ Lysosomal pH ⟶ Inhibits Antigen Processing ⟶ ↓ Antigen-MHC Presentation ⟶ ↓ T-Cell Activation ⟶ Inhibits TLRs ⟶ ↓ Pro-inflammatory Cytokines ⟶ ↓ Inflammation in RA.

Uses
  • Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Prevention and treatment of malaria.
  • Autoimmune diseases like Sjögren's syndrome

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea).
  • Dermatological (rash, pigmentation changes).
  • Ocular toxicity:
    • Vortex keratopathy (cornea verticallata).
    • Posterior subcapsular cataract.
    • Bull’s eye retinopathy (deposits like concentric rings in the retina).
  • Cardiovascular (cardiomyopathy, QT prolongation).
  • Neurological (headache, dizziness).
  • Hematologic (anaemia, leukopenia).

Additional Info
  • Regular ophthalmologic examinations to monitor for retinal toxicity.
  • Maximum safe dose of hydroxychloroquine to minimise the risk of bull's-eye maculopathy, is recommended to be 5 mg/kg of real body weight per day.

questions.text: A 33-year-old male patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) has been undergoing treatment with methotrexate for the past two years. Despite the treatment, his disease activity has worsened, prompting the addition of a newer drug. Six months later, he got married, and subsequently, the couple faced difficulty conceiving, which was attributed to the new medication. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Sulfasalazine

Mechanism of Action

Sulfasalazine⟶ Active Metabolites ⟶ Inhibits Cyclooxygenase/Lipoxygenase ⟶ ↓ Prostaglandins/Leukotrienes ⟶ ↓ Inflammation in GI Tract and Joints + Immunomodulation + Antimicrobial Effects.

Uses
  • IBD ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

Side Effects
  • Gastrointestinal( nausea, vomiting, diarrhea).
  • Headache.
  • Rash.
  • Blood disorders like leukopenia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Liver dysfunction.
  • Reversible infertility in males (oligospermia).

Additional Info
  • Administered cautiously in patients with known sulfa allergies.
  • Monitoring of blood counts and liver function is recommended during therapy.

questions.text: Match the following Biologicals with their respective MOA. BIOLOGICALS MOA a) Rituximab i) Anti-TNFα b) Anakinra ii) Anti-IL6 c) Infliximab iii) Anti-IL1 d) Tocilizumab iv) CD20
questions.explanation:
Mechanism of Action (MOA)

Biological Drug

TNF-alpha inhibitor
  • Adalimumab
  • Etanercept
  • Infliximab

IL-6 receptor antagonist
  • Tocilizumab
  • Sarilumab

CD20-directed cytolytic monoclonal antibody
  • Rituximab

CTLA-4 Ig fusion protein
  • Abatacept

IL-1 receptor antagonist
  • Anakinra

questions.text: Which of the following is not a Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitor?
questions.explanation:
Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitors

Drugs
  • Baricitinib (Option A)
  • Upadacitinib (Option B)
  • Tofacitinib (Option C

MOA

JAK Inhibitor⟶ Inhibits JAKs ⟶ Blockade of Cytokine Signaling ⟶ ↓ Inflammatory Mediators ⟶ ↓ Inflammation in GI Tract and Joints + Immunomodulation.

Uses

Mnemonic: “RAJPUT”

  • Rheumatoid Arthritis
  • Ankylosing Spondylitis
  • Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis
  • Psoriatic Arthritis
  • Ulcerative Colitis is
  • Tofacitinib

Side Effects
  • Increased risk of infections
  • Liver enzyme elevation
  • Gastrointestinal disturbances
  • Headache
  • Fatigue
  • Increased cholesterol levels
